definition: Zhao Yun (-229), general of Shu in Romance of the Three Kingdoms
to surpass (old)
surname Zhao/one of the seven states during the Warring States Period (476-220 BC)/the Former Zhao 前趙 (304-329) and Later Zhao 後趙 (319-350), states of the Sixteen Kingdoms
cloud/CL:朵[duo3]
(classical) to say
surname Yun/abbr. for Yunnan Province 雲南省|云南省[Yun2 nan2 Sheng3]

sentences.english: Then Wang Ping crossed the river and submitted to Zhao Zilong, who took the defector to Xuande.
sentences.chinese: 王平渡汉水来投赵云，云引见玄德。

sentences.english: Zilong was helpless. With Ah Dou in his arms, how could he shift the boat toward shore?
sentences.chinese: 赵云孤掌难鸣，只护得阿斗，安能移舟傍岸。

sentences.english: Any idiot knows zhao yun is not gonna let his zu gong get killed.
sentences.chinese: 任何白痴都知道赵云不会让他的主公被杀的。

sentences.english: That night the 2 men and their company surrendered to Zhao Zilong.
sentences.chinese: 当夜二人引五百军径奔赵云寨来投降。

sentences.english: Zhao Yun and Liu Bei's special relationship allowed him to do things others did not dare to do.
sentences.chinese: 赵云和刘备的特殊关系，使他敢做别人不敢做的事。

sentences.english: Fearing that Zhuge Liang might be murdered, Liu Bei send Zhao Yun with 500warriors to protect him.
sentences.chinese: 刘备怕诸葛亮被害，派赵云带五百军士保护。

sentences.english: With a short, sharp cry Zilong, spear leveled, went straight for Chunyu Dao.
sentences.chinese: 赵云大喝一声，挺枪纵马，直取淳于导。

definition: Lü Bu (-198), general and warlord

Guan Yu (-219), general of Shu and blood-brother of Liu Bei in Romance of the Three Kingdoms, fearsome fighter famous for virtue and loyalty/posthumously worshipped and identified with the guardian Bodhisattva Sangharama
Zhang Fei (168-221), general of Shu and blood-brother of Liu Bei in Romance of the Three Kingdoms, famous as fearsome fighter and lover of wine
Huang Zhong (-220), general of Shu in Romance of the Three Kingdoms, portrayed as an old fighter
Ma Chao (176-222), general of Shu in Romance of the Three Kingdoms
Liu Bei (161-223), warlord at the end of the Han dynasty and founder of the Han kingdom of Shu 蜀漢|蜀汉 (c. 200-263), later the Shu Han dynasty

Cao Cao (155-220), famous statesman and general at the end of Han, noted poet and calligrapher, later warlord, founder and first king of Cao Wei 曹魏, father of Emperor Cao Pi 曹丕/the main villain of novel the Romance of Three Kingdoms 三國演義|三国演义
Zhou Yu or Chou Yü (175-210), famous general of the southern Wu kingdom and victor of the battle of Redcliff/in Romance of the Three Kingdoms, absolutely no match for Zhuge Liang

Zhuge Liang (181-234), military leader and prime minister of Shu Han 蜀漢|蜀汉 during the Three Kingdoms period/the main hero of the fictional Romance of Three Kingdoms 三國演義|三国演义, where he is portrayed as a sage and military genius/mastermind
courtesy name of Zhao Yun 趙雲|赵云[Zhao4 Yun2], general of Shu in Romance of the Three Kingdoms
Sun Ce (175-200), general and major warlord of the Later Han Dynasty
Lü Meng (178-219), general of the southern state of Wu
Pang De (-219), general of Cao Wei at the start of the Three Kingdoms period, victor over Guan Yu 關羽|关羽/Pound (name)/Ezra Pound (1885-1972), American poet and translator
Sun Quan (reigned 222-252), southern warlord and king of state of Wu 吳|吴 in the Three Kingdoms period
Han Xin (-196 BC), famous general of first Han emperor Liu Bang 劉邦|刘邦[Liu2 Bang1]
Liu Chan 劉禪|刘禅 (207-271), son of Liu Bei, reigned as Shu Han emperor 233-263
